questions.text: A young man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He was driving the car when the accident occurred. On examination, it is noted that the injured leg is shortened. The image of the pelvis radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerves is most commonly injured in the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • The femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.
  • Nerve injury: common, sciatic nerve is injured.
  • Arterial injury: rare
  • Nerve injury: rare
  • Arterial injury: relatively more common, Femoral artery is injured

questions.text: For which type of fractures does the Hawkins classification apply?
questions.explanation:
Type I

Undisplaced fracture of the talar neck.

Type II

Displaced fracture with subluxation or dislocation of the subtalar joint.

Type III

Displaced fracture with dislocation of the talus body from the ankle joint.

Type IV

Displaced vertical talar neck fracture with associated disruption of the talonavicular joint.

questions.text: The radiograph below depicts a patient who is experiencing persistent knee pain without any previous injury. Identify the specific condition displayed in the image?

options.label: B
options.text: Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture of the upper pole of the patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.correct_answer: B. Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee
questions.explanation:
Definition

A congenital condition where the patella (kneecap) is divided into two separate bone segments.

Etiology
  • Failure of ossification centers to fuse during development, resulting in separate bone fragments.
  • Occurs in approximately 1-2% of the population, often bilateral.

Anatomy

Typically involves the superolateral corner of the patella.

Types

Based on the location of the secondary ossification centre,

  • Type I: Inferior pole of patella.
  • Type II: Lateral margin.
  • Type III: Superolateral (most common).

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic, but can cause anterior knee pain, especially after trauma or repetitive stress.

Diagnosis

X-ray: Shows the patella with a well-corticated fragment.

MRI: Useful for assessing associated soft tissue injury or bone edema if symptomatic.

Differential Diagnosis

Patellar fracture (differs by smooth, rounded edges in bipartite patella vs sharp edges in fractures).

Management
  • Asymptomatic: No treatment required.
  • Symptomatic: Rest, NSAIDs, physical therapy, or in severe cases, surgery (excision of fragment).

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a child brought to the orthopedics OPD with a lower limb deformity and hyperpigmented skin lesions, based on the presented X-ray of her thigh?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Non-inherited developmental disorder causing replacement of bone by fibrous tissue

Etiology
  • GNAS1 gene mutation (Chromosome 20)
  • Associated with McCune Albright syndrome - Polyostotic Fibrous Dysplasia

Clinical presentation
  • Usually presents in the 2nd decade
  • Progressive limb pain, swelling
  • Limb deformities with associated fractures
  • Skin lesions (seen with McCune Albright syndrome)

Radiography
  • X-ray: well defined expansile intramedullary lesions with ‘Ground glass’ appearance, ‘shepherd crook deformity’.
  • MRI: is done to know the full extent of the disease

Management
  • Medical: Bisphosphonates
  • Surgical: Deformity correction surgeries

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis based on the x-ray image of a 22-year-old female?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient has limited hip movement and complains of pain and discomfort in the hip region. Which of the following tests is done to identify flexion deformity at the hip?

A 80-year-old woman slipped and fell in the bathroom, experiencing pain and an inability to walk due to a left hip injury, without any prior osteoarthritis history, and with an observation of a shortened and externally rotated left lower limb according to X-ray findings, how would you plan to manage her condition?

A young male who met with a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his lower limb was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.explanation:
Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • The femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.
  • Nerve injury: common, sciatic nerve is injured.
  • Arterial injury: rare
  • Nerve injury: rare
  • Arterial injury: relatively more common, Femoral artery is injured

questions.text: A 74-year-old man, who was previously a weightlifter, presented with lower back pain that was radiating to his legs. On examination , a palpable step was felt in the lumbosacral region of the spine. The x-ray of the spine is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Spondylolisthesis

               

  • It refers to the forward displacement of a vertebra over the one beneath it
  • Commonly occurring at the L5-S1 and L4-L5 levels.
  • Spondylolysis refers to a defect in the pars without the vertebra slipping forward.

Classification

Dysplastic

  • Least common type
  • Caused by congenital anomalies in the upper sacrum or L5 arch, facilitating the slip.

Isthmic

  • The most common type
  • Involving a lesion in the pars interarticularis, which can be further divided into three subtypes:
  • Lytic: A fatigue fracture of the pars interarticularis.
  • Intact but elongated: The pars interarticularis remains intact but is elongated.
  • Acute fracture: A recent fracture of the pars interarticularis. The defect causes the anterior half of the vertebra to slip forward while the posterior half remains with the lower vertebra.

Degenerative

  • Results from long-term intersegmental instability, where the pars remains intact, but degenerative changes in the facet joints permit forward slipping.
  • Common in older adults, where instability in the posterior facet joints due to osteoarthritis can lead to displacement, occasionally backwards (retrolisthesis).
  • Severe displacement and neurological issues are rare.

Traumatic

This results from fractures in other parts of the bony structure rather than in the pars interarticularis.

Pathological

Caused by generalized or localized bone diseases that weaken the vertebral articulations.

Normal appearance

Spondylolysis (Option A)

Spondylolisthesis (Option B)
  • Resembles a Scottish dog
  • Collar Appearance: Indicates a defect in the isthmus (pars interarticularis)
  • Defect without vertebral displacement
  • Separated Head and Neck
  • Defect with vertebral displacement

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the fracture shown in the image, which occurred due to a fall from a significant height?
questions.explanation:
Type A: Stable (Intact posterior arch)

A1

Avulsion injury

A2

Iliac-wing or anterior arch fracture

A3

Transverse sacrococcygeal fracture

Type B: Partially stable (incomplete disruption of the posterior arch)

B1

Open-book injury (external rotation) (Option A)

B2

Lateral-compression injury (internal rotation)

B2-1: Ipsilateral anterior and posterior injuries

B2-2: Contralateral (bucket-handle) injuries (Option D)

 

B3

Bilateral

Type C: Unstable (complete disruption of the posterior arch)

C1

Unilateral

C2

Bilateral, with one side type B, one side type C

C3

Bilateral

questions.text: A 45-year old female met with an accident and was brought to trauma centre and X-ray pelvis was performed and image is given below shows Intracapsular fracture NOF. What is the management in this case?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Neck of Femur Fracture

Intertrochanteric Fracture

Location

Intracapsular (within the joint capsule)

Extracapsular (outside the joint capsule)

Age Group

Typically after 50 years

Typically after 60 years

Sex

Female > Male

Male > Female

Common Patient Demographics

Elderly (low-energy trauma like falls)

Elderly (low-energy trauma); rare high-energy trauma in younger patients

Mechanism of Injury

Trivial, low-energy trauma (osteoporotic)

Low-energy trauma in elderly; usually requires significant trauma in younger patients

Stability

Less stable, especially if displaced

Generally unstable due to muscle forces and location

Ability to Walk

May be possible in impacted fractures

Walking is not possible due to the instability

External Rotation Deformity

Less than 45º

More than 45º

Shortening

Less than 1 inch

More than 1 inch

Blood Supply Involvement

High risk of avascular necrosis (medial circumflex artery disruption)

Lower risk of avascular necrosis

Blood Loss

Less blood loss due to intracapsular location

More blood loss due to the involvement of surrounding vascular structures

Pain, Severity, and Tenderness

Mild to moderate pain localized to the groin/hip region. Tenderness is typically felt in Scarpa’s triangle.

Severe pain, more generalized around the hip with marked tenderness over the greater trochanter. Weight-bearing is difficult or impossible.

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced: Internal fixation (Option D) (e.g., cannulated screws)
  • Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty (Option B ruled out), total hip replacement)

Almost always requires internal fixation (e.g., dynamic hip screws, intramedullary nails)

Complications

High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis

Malunion is more common than nonunion

questions.text: Arrange the following in the correct sequence for the Thomas test: 1. Squaring of pelvis 2. Flexion of the hip 3. Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis 4. Measure actual flexion deformity 5.Make sure that the ischial tuberosity makes contact with the ground. 6. Overcorrection of the normal side

A 45-year-old patient with a cast, due to tibia fracture, presented to the emergency department with complaints of intense pain. The cast was removed and on physical examination, passive extension of leg was painful. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were present and there was a loss of sensation over the first web space. What is the next step?
questions.correct_answer: C. Measure the anterior compartment pressure

questions.text: After a fracture in the femoral shaft, your consultant instructs you to apply tibia traction. Which of the following will you ask the nurse to provide? 1. Thomas splint 2. K-wire 3. Steinmann pin 4. Denham's pin 5. Bohler's stirrup 6. Bohler Braun splint
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Orthopaedic Instruments - Surgical Holdings
  • ↳ Proximal femoral nail fixation | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

Instrument

Images

Proximal Femur Nail (PFN)

  • The Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN) is used for closed intramedullary fixation of proximal femoral fractures.
  • It features two proximal openings for a femoral neck lag screw and an anti-rotation screw.
  • Indications include peritrochanteric, intertrochanteric, and subtrochanteric fractures.
  • It is contraindicated for medial femoral neck fractures.

Kuntscher Nail

  • Used for internal fixation of femoral fractures.
  • The nail is a hollow tube with a cloverleaf shape for rotational stability.
  • Fixation is based on three-point fixation: at both ends and the isthmus.
  • Each end has an "eye" for the extractor hook during removal.
  • Nail size is determined by measuring from the greater trochanter to the lateral knee joint line and subtracting 2 cm.
  • About 2 cm of the nail is left protruding at the trochanter for removal, usually 2 years post-operation.

Kirschner wire (K wire)

  • Thin, straight steel wire with a diameter of 1 to 3 mm.
  • Uses include:
    • Internal fixation of small bones.
    • Tension band wiring in patella
    • Applying traction (e.g., through the olecranon).
    • Fixing fractures in children.
    • Used in Ilizarov’s fixation system.

Steinmann Pin

  • Stout, straight steel rod with a diameter of 3 to 6 mm.
  • Primarily used for skeletal traction.
  • Common sites for insertion include the upper end of the tibia, the supracondylar region of the femur, and the calcaneum.

Bohler’s Stirrup

  • A device used for holding a Steinmann pin and applying traction.
  • Side screws secure the pin in place.
  • Allows for changing the direction of traction without moving the pin inside the bone.
  • Helps avoid loosening of the pin during traction adjustments.

Thomas Splint:

  • Primarily for the stabilization and immobilization of fractures in the femur or tibia.
  • It consists of a metal frame that supports the limb, preventing movement and reducing the risk of further injury.

Steinmann Pin:

  • It is a large, stainless steel pin used for internal fixation of fractures or to stabilize bones during surgery.
  • Typically inserted percutaneously (through the skin) or during surgery and is used to hold bones in place for proper healing.

Denham's Pin:

  • It is used for joint stabilization, often in the hip joint.
  • It is inserted into the bone and can be used for traction or temporary stabilization while healing.

Bohler-Braun Splint:

  • Splint used for the immobilization of fractures, especially in the thigh and leg.
  • It is a two-piece splint made of metal and is commonly used for fractures of the femur and tibia.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a patient develops type IIIa compound tibial fracture. Arrange the following external fixators in decreasing order of their stability (highest to lowest) 1. Ilizarov fixator 2. Uniplanar with a single rod 3. Uniplanar with double rod 4. Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod
A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER following a motor vehicle collision complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What will be the next step of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

options.label: D
options.text: Open reduction and reconstruction of posterior pillar of acetabulum

questions.correct_answer: A. Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
questions.explanation:
Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

questions.explanation:
Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B)

Anterior dislocation of hip (Option A)

Central fracture-dislocation of hip (Option C)

Mechanism of injury:

  • Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

  • Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

  • The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.

  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Clinical features:

Clinical features:

questions.text: Which zone demonstrates the most optimal healing in the repair of a meniscal tear?
What could be the potential diagnosis for a 22-year-old male patient presenting with a history of accident, exhibiting leg abduction and external rotation?
questions.correct_answer: A. Anterior dislocation of the hip
questions.explanation:
Anterior hip dislocation

Classification
  • Type I: Pubic (superior) injuries
  • Type II: Obturator (inferior) injuries

Management
  • Reduction should be performed as soon as possible under sedation or general anesthesia.
  • Closed reduction technique:
    • Hold the affected leg in external rotation, abduction, and flexion.
    • Apply longitudinal traction.
    • Internally and externally rotate the leg until reduction is achieved, and apply anterior pressure on the femoral head if necessary.
    • If repeated attempts fail, consider an open reduction.

Complications
  • Injury to the sciatic nerve.
  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head: may require hip replacement if osteoarthritis develops.

 

 

  •   Osteoarthritis: develops years later. Treatment varies from conservative to total hip replacement.

 

  • Myositis Ossificans: Develops weeks to months post-injury and is characterized by pain and stiffness. Ill-advised vigorous and improper massage following trauma is the most common cause.Treatment includes rest and analgesics.

 

  • Potential for associated femoral head fractures.

Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B ruled out)

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central fracture-dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:

  • Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

  • Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

  • The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit 48 hours after fracturing their femur, with a saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit at 100%, but their SpO 2 remained at 60%? The patient is also experiencing confusion, and a chest radiograph shows clear lung fields.
questions.explanation:
Fat Embolism
  • Fat embolism is a multi-organ disorder caused by fat globules entering the bloodstream, commonly occurring after high-risk orthopedic injuries, particularly femur fractures.

Classic Triad
  • Hypoxia
  • Petechiae
  • Altered mental status

Other Symptoms

  • Tachycardia, fever, anemia, thrombocytopenia, pulmonary dysfunction (e.g., tachypnea, respiratory acidosis).

Etiology
  • Young adults (20-30 years): Long bone fractures
  • Iatrogenic cause: Occurs after intramedullary (IM) nailing of the femur.

Pathogenesis

  • Following injury, fat from bone marrow or platelet agglutination enters injured vessels and travels as emboli, leading to various clinical manifestations.

Investigation
  • Chest X-ray: Commonly clear lung fields, occasionally Snowstorm appearance is seen (pathognomonic)
  • PaO₂ <60 mm Hg
  • Platelet count <1.5 lakhs
  • ECG: Prominent S-wave
  • Other lab findings: Anemia, hypocalcemia
  • CT scan and MRI: Assess severity

Management

  • Respiratory support: Oxygen or ventilator support to restore PaO₂
  • Drug therapy:
    • Steroids: Reduce lung inflammation and improve gas exchange.
    • Heparin: Lipolytic and antiplatelet agent.
    • Low molecular weight dextran: Increases plasma volume.
    • Antibiotics and other supportive care.
  • Definitive fracture treatment: Early fixation to prevent worsening.

questions.text: In the case of an ongoing bleeding in a patient with a fracture of the pelvic bone, what is the immediate action that needs to be taken to address the situation, if the patient is in hypotension?

A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of back pain, stiffness, and recurrent episodes of eye pain with redness. On examination, they are found to have anterior uveitis and sacroiliitis. Which of the following HLA is commonly involved
questions.explanation:
Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)
 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

 

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)
 

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint

 
  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae

 
  • Bamboo spine

 
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign

 
  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test
 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test


 

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance
 

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)
 

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

Conditions mimicking Ankylosing Spondylitis with spinal fusion
  • Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH) (Forestier’s disease)
  • Ossification of Posterior Longitudinal Ligament (OPLL)
  • Spondylosis (Degenerative Disc Disease)
  • Psoriatic Arthritis
  • Enteropathic Arthritis (IBD-associated)
  • Reactive Arthritis
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
  • Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA)

A patient presents with 5th metatarsal fracture. For how many days he/she would have to wear cast?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C

questions.explanation: Correct Option B - L5

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Spinous Process Fractu

Feature Description
Location Anterior proximal tibia (tibial tuberosity)
Mechanism Forceful contraction of quadriceps (e.g., jumping, kicking)
Radiograph finding Fracture through or below the tibial tuberosity
Associated conditions May be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease as a predisposing factor

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with back pain for six months. Her CT scan image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C – Spondylolisth

questions.text: A patient suffers an inversion injury to the ankle. Which structure is most likely to get injured?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Anterior talofibular lig

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture in a patient who sustained a road traffic accident resulting in fractures of both the tibia and fibula.
questions.explanation:
The tibial plateau refers to the proximal tibial surface, which comprises the medial and lateral articular surfaces of the respective tibial condyles.

Lateral tibial plateau fractures are the most common.

Mechanism of Injury
  • The main mechanism of injury is a varus or valgus force, with or without axial load.
  • Young Adults: Road traffic accidents, leading to split fractures (high ligament injury risk).

  • Elderly: Trivial falls, causing depression or split depression fractures (associated with osteoporosis) (low ligament injury risk).

Classification (Schatzker)

Type I: Lateral plateau split fracture (young adults).

Type II: Lateral plateau split depression (young adults).

Type III: Lateral plateau pure depression (elderly).

Type IV: Medial plateau fracture.

Type V: Bicondylar fracture.

Type VI: Dissociation of metaphysis and diaphysis.

Clinical Features
  • Knee swelling due to hemarthrosis.
  • Inability to bear weight
  • Reduce range of knee movements
  • Compartment syndrome (earliest sign: stretch pain).

Imaging
  • X-ray: Initial fracture detection.

 

   

 

  • CT with 3D Reconstruction: Gold standard.
  • MRI: To assess ligament injuries.

Management
  • Non-surgical: Stable fractures with minimal displacement.
  • Surgical (ORIF): For displaced fractures or significant depression.
  • Ligament reconstruction if needed.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a fracture of the intracapsular neck of the femur. What is the standard management done in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Details
Common in Elderly, especially osteoporotic bones
Type of fracture Intracapsular (femoral neck, within joint capsule)
Risk Disruption of blood supply → avascular necrosis
Goal of treatment Restore mobility, minimize complications of immobility
Preferred treatment (elderly) Hemiarthroplasty – replacement of femoral head
Preferred treatment (young) Internal fixation with cannulated screws or DHS

questions.text: Which of he following layer is affected in a Salter-Harris type 1 fracture ?

options.label: A
options.text: Calcific zone of the growth plate

options.label: B
options.text: Hypertrophic zone of the growth plate

options.label: C
options.text: The resting zone of the growth plate

options.label: D
options.text: Through the whole of the epiphysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Hypertrophic zone of the growth plate
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Hypertrophic or calcific

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a proximal 1/3rd fracture of shaft of femur. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Interlocking

questions.text: In a 70-year-old female who presents with extracapsular neck of femur fracture, what is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Intramedullary

questions.text: The diagnosis in a patient who is unable to do internal and external rotation of the hip is?
questions.explanation:
Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to lesser trochanter?
questions.explanation:
Hip Flexor Muscle

Origin

Attachment

Function

Iliopsoas (Psoas major + Iliacus)
  • Psoas major: Transverse processes of T12-L5 vertebrae
  • Iliacus: Iliac fossa of the pelvis
  • Both muscles combine and attach at the lesser trochanter of the femur
  • Primary hip flexor
  • Flexion of the hip joint
  • Assists in trunk flexion (psoas)

Rectus Femoris
  • Anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) and acetabulum
  • Tibial tuberosity via the patellar tendon
  • Flexion of the hip
  • Extends the knee

Sartorius
  • Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)
  • Medial surface of the tibia (Pes anserinus)
  • Flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the hip
  • Flexion of the knee

Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL)
  • Anterior part of the iliac crest
  • Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)
  • Iliotibial band (ITB), which attaches to the lateral condyle of the tibia
  • Flexion and abduction of the hip
  • Medial rotation of the hip

Pectineus
  • Pectineal line of the pubis
  • Pectineal line of the femur
  • Flexion and adduction of the hip

Adductor Longus
  • Pubic bone near the pubic symphysis
  • Medial linea aspera of the femur
  • Flexion of the hip (when the hip is in extension)
  • Adduction of the hip

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD after a road traffic accident complaining of being unable to dorsiflex and evert the ankle. A X- ray was ordered by the attending physician. In addition to the observed injury on the X-ray, which gait abnormality is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Anatomy:
  • The terminal branch of the sciatic nerve arises from the popliteal fossa.
  • Root value: L4,L5,S1 & S2.
  • Hooks around the neck of the fibula.
  • Terminates by dividing into Superficial peroneal nerve & Deep peroneal nerve

Muscles supplied:
  • Superficial peroneal nerve: Peroneus longus & brevis (foot eversion)
  • Deep peroneal nerve: Peroneus tertius, Tibialis anterior, Extensor digitorum, Extensor hallucis longus.

Cutaneous supply of foot:

Common peroneal nerve injury:

Causes
  • Most common: Neck of fibula fracture
  • Posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Fracture lateral tibial condyle

Clinical features
  • Foot drop (inability to evert)
  • High stepping gait (Option A)

Treatment
  • Conservative (mainstay): Foot drop splint

  • Surgical (tendon transfer) - only done >12 months of no recovery:
    • Barr’s technique
    • Ober’s technique

Scissoring gait

Cerebral palsy

Stepping gait

Foot drop

Ataxic gait

Cerebellar ataxia

Circumduction gait (Option C)

Stroke

Waddling gait (Option B)

Hip abductors palsy

Stamping gait (Option D)

Tabes dorsalis

questions.text: A child presents to the orthopedic OPD with a limp and limb shortening . His X-ray is given below, What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - DDH

Condition

Description

Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)

Abnormal development of the hip joint causing instability or dislocation. It can result in a shortened leg and a limp.

Legg-Calvé-Perthes Disease

Avascular necrosis of the femoral head, leading to hip joint damage, limp, and leg length discrepancy.

Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE)

Displacement of the femoral head from the femoral neck, leading to a limp and limb shortening. More common in adolescents.

Septic Arthritis

Infection of the joint, causing pain, swelling, decreased range of motion, and limping.

Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA)

Chronic inflammation of the joints, including the hip joint, resulting in pain, stiffness, and limping.

Osteomyelitis

Infection of the bone, which can lead to limping, localized pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms.

Periosteal Reaction

A response of the periosteum to various conditions, such as trauma or infection, causing pain, swelling, and sometimes limb shortening.

Leg Length Discrepancy

A difference in leg length, which can result from various causes, including congenital anomalies or previous fractures.

Fractures

Fractures of the hip, femur, or other bones can cause limping and limb shortening.

questions.text: Given below is the X ray of a newborn. What is the type of scoliosis shown in the X-ray ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Congenital S

Idiopathic Scoliosis

Infantile idiopathic scoliosis: develops in children younger than 3 years old.
 

Juvenile idiopathic scoliosis: develops between 3 and 10 years old.
 

Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis: develops between 10 and 18 years old.

Congenital Scoliosis

Present at birth, resulting from abnormal spinal development during fetal development.

Neuromuscular Scoliosis

Associated with underlying neuromuscular conditions (e.g., cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy).

Degenerative Scoliosis

Develops later in life due to degenerative changes in the spine.

Syndromic Scoliosis

Associated with specific genetic syndromes or conditions.

Secondary Scoliosis

Develops as a result of other underlying factors (e.g., tumors, infections, previous surgeries).

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient came with a flexion contracture of the hip. Which of the following test is useful in diagnosis?
Which of the following is true regarding the scar tissue in patellar clunk syndrome?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Superior pole of the patella, impinging during extension

options.label: C
options.text: Inferior pole of the patella, impinging during flexion

options.label: D
options.text: Inferior pole of the patella, impinging during extension

questions.correct_answer: B. Superior pole of the patella, impinging during extension
questions.explanation: Correct Option B

questions.text: A 79 yrs old lady had a fall in the bathroom, the following X-rays were taken in order to make a diagnosis . Which of the following is treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Hemiarth

questions.text: Blount Disease results from the involvement of
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Proximal T

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Posterior dislocation of the hip
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Posterior dislocation of the h

questions.text: Identify the shown image
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Patella Tendon Bearing B

Type

Use/Indication

Ankle Brace

Ankle sprains, instability, post-injury protection

Knee Brace

Ligament injuries (ACL, PCL, MCL, LCL), patellofemoral pain, osteoarthritis

Cervical Collar

Cervical spine injuries, neck pain, whiplash

Hip Abduction Orthosis

Hip fractures, hip dislocations, post-surgical stabilization

Knee Immobilizer

Knee fractures, ligament injuries, post-surgical immobilization

Back Brace

Low back pain, spinal fractures, post-surgical support

Posterior Leg Splint

Tibia or fibula fractures, post-injury immobilization

Air Cast

Ankle fractures, sprains, post-injury protection

Patellar Stabilizing Brace

Patellar instability, patellofemoral pain syndrome, patellar tendonitis

questions.text: Avascular necrosis of the femur head is due to which of the following artery?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Medial Circumflex Femoral A

questions.text: Football player gets blow to the outer knee during match. Which structure is most commonly associated with this type of injury?
questions.explanation:
Clinical History

Ligaments Commonly Injured

Valgus stress injury

Medial collateral ligament (MCL)

Hyperextension injury

Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL)

Pivot shift mechanism

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)

Direct blow to the knee

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), Medial collateral ligament (MCL), Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), Lateral collateral ligament (LCL)

Rotational force injury

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), Medial collateral ligament (MCL), Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), Lateral collateral ligament (LCL), Medial meniscus, Lateral meniscus

questions.text: Evaluate the following statements with respect to inter – trochanteric fracture , and opt for the correct ones : More common in males than females One – year mortality rate is about 20 to 30% It is more commonly associated with non – union than fracture neck of femur One year mortality rate can be reduced by operating within 48 hours

A 34-year-old male has been suffering from a progressive lower backache and early morning stiffness for the past six months. His symptoms are more severe in the morning and improve with exercise. He is a known case of ulcerative colitis. An X-ray of his lumbar spine is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Ankylosing

Feature

Ankylosing spondylitis 

Psoriatic arthritis 

Rheumatoid arthritis 

Predominant joints affected

Spine and sacroiliac joints
 

Peripheral joints
 

Small joints of hands and feet

Radiographic findings

Sacroiliitis, erosions, or sclerosis of the spine
 

Joint space narrowing, bone erosions, bone proliferation
 

Joint space narrowing, bone erosions

Association with other comorbidities

Inflammatory bowel disease

Psoriasis, uveitis

Sjogren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus

Pattern of joint involvement

Symmetric, may affect entire spine

Symmetric or asymmetric, dactylitis common

Symmetrical involvement of small joints of hands and feet

questions.text: A young patient presented to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee . A plain radiograph is shown below. What is the best treatment for this condition?

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a noticeable deformity of the neck and upper back. On physical examination, the patient's scapula is observed to be elevated and medially rotated, giving it the appearance of an equilateral triangle. The patient also has limited neck mobility. The patient and their family report that the deformity has been present since birth and has not improved over time. What is the likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct option C - Klippel-F
